Certainly! The American Civil Rights Movement is a fascinating period in history, and there are many excellent books and movies that offer insights into this transformative era. Here are some suggestions:

Books:
1. "The Autobiography of Malcolm X" by Malcolm X and Alex Haley - This classic autobiography offers a personal and political account of Malcolm X's life and his role in the civil rights movement. 2. "Bearing the Cross" by David Garrow - This Pulitzer Prize-winning biography of Martin Luther King Jr. offers a detailed account of King's leadership, his strategies for social change, and his personal struggles and challenges. 3. "Eyes on the Prize: America's Civil Rights Years, 1954-1965" by Juan Williams and Julian Bond - This book is the companion to the award-winning documentary series "Eyes on the Prize" and provides a comprehensive history of the civil rights movement. Movies:
1. "Selma" (2014) - This historical drama focuses on the pivotal Selma to Montgomery march led by Martin Luther King Jr. in 1965 and the Civil Rights Act that followed. 2. "13th" (2016) - This documentary explores the relationship between race, mass incarceration, and the US criminal justice system, tracing the legacy of slavery and the civil rights movement in contemporary America. 3. "The Butler" (2013) - This historical drama follows the life of a White House butler who served eight US presidents from Eisenhower to Reagan and provides a perspective on the civil rights movement from inside the White House. I hope you enjoy these recommendations and find them informative!
